author: kstrickley

title: not THAT cheap BUT NOW for the lazy: V2 - automatic hotend nozzle cleaner / brush

description.text:
This is version 2 of my cheap automatic cleaner brush: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:950249

http://youtu.be/mUeDcgkfJoQ

usability-update, 3 months later: looks like new. no heat-damage to the brushes. highly recommended!

I know, we are all lazy! So I designed it for the comfort we need ;-)

This time you will get the same convenient automatic cleaning of your nozzle, but now you can pay 5$ to save you an hour of DIY-hacking-time.

  • Buy a pack of 12 Nylon-brushes for 5$ on ebay: http://goo.gl/HbVT9r
  • Put each of them into the printed mount
  • Mount the whole assemble and adjust it to the prefered position (it should just touch the nozzle and not the heaterblock)
  • write a START-Gcode to move the hotend all accross the mounted brush
  • Be happy with a clean hotend

author: holbr99952

title: Open WarHex - modular, scenic 3D Hex terrain project

description.text:
Open WarHex is my personal project to make a modular, scenic terrain system for my tabletop gaming. I have a thermoplastic filament 3D printer and access to plastic injection molding equipment, and these are designed to be buildable both as additive 3D prints, and subtractive machined molds used for plastic injection in ABS.

The Open WarHex is a 1.35" (nominal 1.5") hex with a .2" gutter, for a full diameter of 1.75". Height per layer is .75" The gutter allows for seamless and secure vertical stacking. The gutter also features a self-centering contour for a secondary modular ring base that complex scenery additions such as forest lines or smoke walls can be built on. This allows the hex to be surrounded with modular, movable scenery or details, but leaves ample room in the center for a miniature to still occupy the hex itself.

These terrain pieces can create an awesome, three-dimensional, visually striking tabletop battlefield - especially with some finishing work, such as painting and flocking.

Current pieces include plain single and double hexes and the modular scenery ring. Triple hexes and twelve hex flat areas will be included soon. Compatible scenery parts such as flame hex markers, smoke columns, and other modules will be added over time. Specialty hexes such as roads, water, rough terrain, and others may also be added based on interest.

Anyone that wishes to make compatible hex or scenery parts is welcome to do so, under the Open WarHex banner.

I play tabletop BattleTech, but this terrain system is usable for a wide variety of tabletop games.

Feedback is appreciated! Please leave suggestions, experiences, critical failure analysis, gripes, squawks, wishlists, and any other input you feel could help improve and expand Open WarHex!

RouseauWorks over at Raconteur Weekly has made a quick video review of Open WarHex, check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xHQYE46uuRg

If working in mm, multiply by 25.4

Designed for single-extruder .5mm ABS filament, but also capable of being used as a master for a subtractive injection mold (my original intent).

Not suitable for small children.

8/26 - Adjusted tolerance (internal dimensions) of module ring for improved fit. May not even be noticeable. We'll see.

8/22 - Added Depth 1, Depth 2, and Depth 3 single hexes. These are meant to be used without hexes above them, although Depth 1 and Depth 2 will still stack (Depth 3 will not, it has a flat base). The central hex area is recessed instead of raised, to help the miniature feel submerged. All three will accept a scenery module ring.

8/21 - Version 2! Pins on module ring eliminated by using self-centering contours on main hex. Gutter increased to 0.2". This provides more room for scenery details and more part strength. Per-tile height (minus central hex platform) reduced to .75". Three hex and twelve hex parts added. All parts have been revised to new specs, so please update any local copies.

comments.text: I am having a weird problem with these files in my slicer software. I have used both Slic3er and cura, and they come up in the software as tiny. Well under the reported 1.75" size. Is there some setting I need to change?
comments.author: Charmen85

comments.text: These files are exported in decimal inches (since I set 3ds Max up in inch units to build them and switching units back and forth doesn't end well once you set it one way for a model).  So to get to millimeters, you need to make them 25.4 times bigger - so scale by 2540%.
comments.author: Charmen85

comments.text: Thank you so much. I am still new to 3d printing and getting used to all of these little quirks.

comments.text: I recently printed a few, and they are awesome, and the rings fit perfectly.  My one question is how do you get them to stay stacked?  They do sit nicely on top of one another but not very secure.

comments.text: The ones I have printed more or less self-centered the same way as the modular rings.  I've kept them a little thinner at the bottom edge (primarily a design choice for injection molding) so there definitely is some wiggle room.  It's one of the spots I want to try and work on.

comments.text: I was thinking, as I was mocking up some terrain, that it would be handy if they had just a square ridge/channel on the faces of the raised hexes so they would stay together nicely.  My thought is just to have a box full of 1-height hexes that can be stacked and arranged to make any terrain required on the fly, and was thinking I might need to keep a wad of stick-tack nearby just to put a little bit in between each hex and its neighbour.  Have you thought of doing anything like this to keep the various bits together?
comments.author: hmarcbower

comments.text: Do you mean on the top or the sides?  I've avoided having interlocking tabs on the sides for a couple of reasons, primarily to maintain the suitability of these for injection molding, and partially to avoid any appearance of infringement on the HeroScape tiles.
comments.author: hmarcbower

comments.text: Extremely cool. This will be the first thing to print once my M3D Micro arrives :D

comments.text: Tabletop Battletech... exactly what I was hoping for. :)  However, these are bigger than the map hexes... I was hoping to use these to place on top of the battlemats to 3D-ify the hills and terrain.  Any chance you've figured out the magic scale percentage required to match the size of the battlemaps for the BT game?
comments.author: hmarcbower

comments.text: The printed maps (paper maps and the vinyl / tagboard maps with the most recent core box set) use a 1.25" hex, so if scale these down to fit that, the center area becomes too small for a hex-based miniature to fit.  Once I have this system fleshed out some, I may revisit the 1.25" hex scale with a similar setup.  It's kind of its own can of worms. : )
comments.author: hmarcbower

comments.text: I would also love the original size :/
comments.author: GarageBay9

comments.text: I didn't realize there would be so much interest in a 1.25" hex.  I think I'll need to add that category to the project as soon as the schedule craziness subsides on my end. : )
comments.author: ForAiur

comments.text: Years after my first question I got my Prusa MK2s now :D Did any of your plans to fork this for 1.25 start or are you lost low on time or motivation :D ?
comments.author: GarageBay9

comments.text: ForAiur - well, my wife and I had a second kid, and I've changed jobs a few times, so I've been a little busy... :D  But mostly I ran into an engineering issue; at 1.25" hexes, I kept having problems getting the edge rings to fit well, so I actually converted it entirely to a small plate that sat on top of the hex...  and that's where progress stopped.  I'm not saying I won't come back to it, but I've got a LOT of projects higher on the list.  Sorry.
comments.author: ForAiur

comments.text: That really sounds like a lot more important things :) good to hear that you were still tinkering around a little. Good luck with family and job(s)!
comments.author: GarageBay9

comments.text: So I printed using the "single_hex.stl" model, and adjusted the sizing.  I made the flat-to-flat dimension (Y) 32.2mm, the point-to-point dimension 36.67mm (X) (I actually adjusted the Y value with uniform scaling turned on, and that's what X ended up being), and then turned off uniform scaling to set the height to double at 32.2mm as well (my personal preference, but was also interested to see how the tapers at the top would turn out with the scaling).  Then I printed the "module_ring.stl" file with the same X and Y dimensions (which is about a half a mm bigger than would be suggested by scaling it to the same ratio as the single hex... but I've always found that things I print on my Makerbot are often too tight a fit) - then doubled the height as well to 4.62mm to match the scaling on the single_hex.stl.  Printed out four of each, and they turned out great!  The top ring fits perfectly so that it's snug and won't fall off, but I don't have to exert much pressure to settle them into place.
comments.author: GarageBay9

comments.text: Next on the additions list is likely to be cityscape-type tiles (roads, side streets, open pavement, etc), potentially with monorail / elevated train tracks, and elevated highways.  Beyond that, looking for suggestions and requests!

author: Pilgar

description.text: An artistic vase that was organically formed with cascading levels of supporting handles.
Made with Modo.

There are three versions of this model; the regular version and the hires version and then the stretched version. The photo of the print shows the regular version (slightly faceted). If you have a printer that supports more resolution then use the hires version. If you have problems slicing the hires version, try the regular version. I have also included the file in Thing format for Makerbot printers. The stretched version is elongated in the vertical axis - I think a bit more elegant. This looks good with the PLA gradient material from filaments.ca:

https://filaments.ca/products/gradient-pla-filament-multicolored-1-75mm?variant=3118455556

title: Hammerhead Kinect grip w/alt mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is a combination of both The Hammerhead Kinect grip by tbuser, and the Kinect mount made by Henkka.

I liked the idea of the grip, as well as the idea of not having to screw the mount into the actual Kinect.

I Edited the mount so that you can use a paperclip in slots on the sides to remove it from the base of the kinect. I also shortened the front and back to make it flush with the base. Some hole sizes on both objects were also changed to account for the nuts and bolts i had on hand. Adjust as needed.

  1. Print all 3 pieces
  2. Affix the pieces to one another
  3. Work the clips into the base of the Kinect
  4. For added stability, use zip ties around the mount and base of the Kinect.

comments.text:
Cool ! Jusdt printed with my Up ! mini in 35mm, normal speed, done great ! When I tried to put the tripod mount in the kinect the small pieces broke but I put rubber bands and that holds on perfectly ! :D

To organize my hundreds assorted parts, laying around hidden in little boxes, i made them a new home on my workshop desk. Also for me fun by sorting and turning around them in circles.

It's designed to get build with common M8 mechanic parts like nuts, washers and a threaded rod.
Depending of your decision and the physical limits you can scale it in different height and count of floors.
Every tray could be easy removed and attached for gathering it's content.

Like shown on the pictures it may explain itself the assembling.
To fix the main rod in the foot, press one nut in the top and drill the rod in downwards, until it appears in the space underneath the foot. Now lock it tight wit another nut.
The spaces between the floors where kept by another nuts and a washer.

For detailed instructions please goto
http://www.makake.co/en/u/matslab/little-stuff-carousel
and browse the sections there.

author: Peterschotte

title: Customizable ZMR 250 Fatshark 600 TVL Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a fatshark camera mount for a ZMR 250 with customizable camera angle.
I needed more camera angle than the usual 10-20 degree which can be found. So this is 30 degree but can be reduced to approx. 10 degree or increased to 35 degree. Does not need any glue to be mounted, its just held in place by the top plate and the plate below. The camera is held with a small zip tie and the bottom plate.

The design was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:761775 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:886877 for the idea with the zip tie.

Version 1.1:
-tighter fitting so that the camera does not vibrate
-changed zip tie position slightly so that the angle can be set between 10 and 35 degree.

I printed it in PLA with the following settings on a ultimaker:
layer high: 0.15mm
shell: 1.2mm
infill: 20%
bottom/top layer: 0.6mm

In order to change the camera angle, open the SCAD file and change the first line "angle" to your camera angle. Render/export/print and have fun.

Mount the camera with a small zip tie, there are mounting holes for the zip tie.

Inspired from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:145946, but it's only inspiration :) I've modified the thing a lot.

It has a more aerodynamic structure to cool down every part of the ramps. One side is closed, because the air coming from the fan cools down the heatbed a bit. It's made for 40mm fan, but you can customize everything, even fan position, by playing the scad file.

It prints nice without a support. The legs are a bit fragile, so be careful.

title: 3D printed Kitchen project
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I've managed to print a prototype of a kitchen that fits onto a shelf of my bookcase: 56 cm width, 30 cm depth and 25 cm height.

I've printed out the kitchen blocks and cupboards on a Felix 3D Printer version 3. Used filament: PLA. I used a special version (for this 3D printer) of the Cura Engine to slice the objects with 24 % infill, printed with 55 mm speed and normal quality.

Average printing time for each block or cupboard: 10 to eleven hours.

The small attributes I added to this kitchen were printed with my UP! Mini 3D printer in ABS plastic.

title: Parametric Lego Mindstorms GT2/GT3 Timing Belts and Pulleys

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms GT2/GT3 Timing Belts and Pulleys.

The belt width can be altered by changing parameter:
belt_width = 5;

Both GT2 and GT3 are supported in the scad source file. (GT2 has been commented out)

The belt length can be defined in 2 ways:

  • By length: use function: drawTimingBeltByLength(250);
  • By diameter: use function: drawTimingBeltByDiameter(100);

Two kinds of pulleys can be generated:

  • A Drive pulley: use function: drawDrivePulley(25);
  • A normal pulley: use function: drawPulley(10);

suggested material selection:

  • timing belts: NinjaFlex
  • pulleys: PLA or ABS

The timingbelt in action:
https://youtu.be/WwBmdpMC_JI

title: IPI I3 Rework - X Ends for 8mm Acme Screws & Pololu Brass Nuts

description.text:
I really wanted to try the IPI Rework, but I recently switched to 8mm acme lead screws and pololu brass nuts, and the IPI rework is for m5 rods. I remixed the IPI X moter end to accommodate for the 8mm rods and polulu nuts.

IPI Prusa I3 Rework: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:734426

Original rework x ends remix for acme leadscrews by trilithium: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:973846

My remix of trilithiums's x ends for pololu brass nuts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:973846

Lead screws used: http://openbuildspartstore.com/8mm-metric-acme-lead-screw/

Pololu Brass Nuts used: http://www.robot-italy.com/en/2688-traveling-nut-for-tr8-8-p2-threaded-rods.html

Notes
8/20/2015 - I converted the x motor end to fit the pololu brass tr8*8 nuts. I will try to start getting the rest of the ipi rework kit printed soon for testing.

description.text:
Screwdriver Handle for regular Hex bits and for Leatherman's flat bits (which are in turn compatible with the regular hex hole).

This handle was meant to be used with Leatherman's bits so the hole design is flat to better hold onto the tools... however it also has a regular hex hole on the opposite side for plugging normal bits.

This is the 2nd version of this handle, the first one was a prototype and it was quite large, so I reduced it to about 1/3 of its original size and tried to keep it as ergonomic as possible.

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

High

25%

Notes:

Recommended settings are 25% infill with a honeycomb structure, or a 35% infill with rectangles or lines.

I have only tested hexagonal style of infill.

title: Housing for Sainsmart MAX6675 thermocouple amplifier subassembly or similar

description.text:
This is a housing for the MAX6675 thermocouple board available from Sainsmart (or Microcenter). This thing provides some strength and protection for the thermocouple board, and will help to stabilize the temperature of the MAXIM/DALLAS 6675 IC on the board. It is designed to fit without the need for adhesive or fasteners, and has a cutout to allow the TC terminal housing to fit without modification.

Note that the STL gallery view is oriented in the recommended printing orientation, but it can be printed vertically either way without trouble.

Print vertically. The STL is designed to minimize unsupported overhangs, and it is recommended to print without supports if possible. 5% fill and two shell layers provided a nice print in my hands. The housing fits snugly without any adhesive, and the revised version fit all of the three MAX6675 units I tried. There is modest contact with the header pins, so I recommend covering these if you use conductive filament. EMF does not appear to affect the operation of this TC amplifier chip, so normal filaments are fine.

author: macforit

description.text:
These are the printed parts for my huge-ass 6s2p 10000mAh DIY electric longboard LiPo. I used common aluminum profiles found in a hardware store for the outer frame. These ones are the right ones:
http://modelltechnikdirekt.de/Alfer-combitechZ-Aluminium-Rechteck-U-Profil-155-x-275-x-15-blank-1000-mm
I soldered the 5000mah cells myself. Be very careful when doing this! The Pack has a built-in low voltage alarm and a buck converter with usb charging output as well as a dual 4mm and a XT60 connector and a balance port that has to be epoxied into the slit.

Print 4 corners, a usbport and a charging port. The mainplug is optional. Drill holes through the profiles with the parts connected. You can have custom holes that way. Drill them thinner than your screw will be so that it has enough grip inside the plastic.

comments.text: How did you solder the battery tabs to the cables? those are usually Aluminum.. at least in most LiPos I have seen and when I try to solder even with flux it just rolls right off. From what I have gathered online there's quite a few people having the same issue in which aluminum requires a special solder and Flux which I havent been able to find. Any tips are greatly appreciated!
comments.author: korben

comments.text: You're right, soldering the terminals was a huge pain in the ass! Next time I have to solder huge LiPos like that I'll certainly bolt the terminals together with M3/M4 bolts and nuts and I'd recommend anyone to do the same!
comments.author: korben

comments.text: how did you wire everything together ive been wondering how to do this for a while
comments.author: Connor98

comments.text: The thing is wired together like a regular 6s lipo (just google that one) with the boost converter in parallel to the +ive and -ive. The Lipo alarm thingy connects to the balance port just like is normally would, just hard-wired.

author: dantedagata

description.text:
This is a handy tool that helps you join filaments 1.75 mm diameter.
I have tested it with PLA

You need a soldering iron with variable temperature.
I have used 180 degrees Celsius for all of my joins.

Only this tool worked for me and gave me repetitive results

Made with FreeCAD

Do not use lighter or a soldering iron without temperature control it will just burn your PLA.

Set up :
Step 1 ) Print the item using 20% infill 0.2mm or more layer height
Step 2 ) Infill a PTFE tube at the 4mm hole and cut the tube flush
Step 3 ) If you need to extract the joined filament not from the end of it cut the PTFE tube like the picture
Step 4) Insert the two M3 nuts
Step 5) Screw the two M3 8 mm bolts

How to use :
Step 1 ) Insert the up (old) filament from the top that has the PTFE tube (blue filament at the pictures). The top filament should be 2 mm out from the PTFE tube
Step 2) Use a screw driver in order to adjust the top screw in order to increase friction at the top filament but at the same time can slide
Step 3) Infill the (new) filament from the bottom (black)
Place it 5 mm from the bottom.
Step 4) Secure the bottom screw firmly.
Step 5) Use the soldering iron at 180 degrees and heat both of the edges at the same time
Notice that the edges should not be placed at the center of the pliers. The top edge should be shorter that the bottom one.
Step 6) Squeeze the pliers

comments.text:
Used it to splice some scraps of PETG together.
After some practice it works great. Thank you!

description.text: KINGDOM HEARTS ATTEMPT

Using two one-inch vending machine capsules (the acorn style) I created a way to carry around your favorite small things.

The design is very simple and can be adapted by adding your own detail to the exterior. I have uploaded a very plain cylinder, and one that is detailed with a honeycombed contour.

In the sample photos, I'm using it to store a flash drive.

The loop can be enlarged as you see fit in order to accommodate different chains or strings. I used a gold chain (ironically came in one of the vending capsules) to show it here.

Not much to tell. Should print as is, but there may be some support for the overhangs, but they're needed for the capsule to snap properly.

Note that with slight variations in capsule sizes and printer accuracy, test printing is advised, and appropriate scaling should be done to fit your capsules.

You can buy the capsules at any store, practically, but you can also buy them bulk on eBay for very low prices.

I rebuilt rsee360's model in OpenSCAD to make it easier to resize it to fit larger wheels after buying the 7/8" Prime Line M-6153. You still need the carriage from the original design, and even at 3/4", it does not exactly match the original model, so it's probably best not to mix and match the wheel carriers.

After building this, I've found the Prime Line wheels far too wobbly for my tastes. I like the overall design of this part, so I'm looking at getting wheels with proper bearings and modifying this design to fit those instead.

title: FPV Video Receiver Mount for the Back of a Monitor

description.text:
If you use an FPV monitor and external receiver, this can give you a solid mounting platform for fitting your receiver to the back of your monitor then be able to remove it. The first part of this mount bolts to the top two holes of the the standard mounting threads included in the back of many monitors. The second part of this mount is fixed to your receiver(s) with double sided tape. Then, when you want to attach your receiver to the back of your monitor, you just have to bolt it in with the bottom two bolts. The lip on the top of the mount holds the top tight so it's very solid.

If you have two receivers, you can print a second device mount so that you can switch between the two easily.

There are a few different device mounts. There are different sizes as well as some have the slots for tying cables up in different locations. All will fit the base, you just need to find out which one fits your receiver and cabling the best.

Although I designed it for use with rig that has everything mounted on the transmitter (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:930215), it could also be useful for anyone with tripod setups. Keeping the receiver attached to the monitor makes field setup much easier.

Please let me know if you made one or have any ideas. I'll also put the sketchup source files online if anyone wants them.

Print one base and the device mount that fits best. I used two M4x6mm hex bolts for the top and two M4x10mm bolts for the bottom.

I used a 0.4mm nozzle, 0.275 layer height, 20% infill, 3 solid perimeter layers and PLA. 10% infill will work too, but I'd stick with at least 3 solid perimeter layers since this will strengthen the bolt holes.

I made this to give my interior a custom look. It turned out great.

Check out the instructional video of how to put it together at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-38LASkvTYc

The letters are a little bit big, unfortunately, to fit into their holes. I had to do a lot filing and actually took off the bottom few layers to get them to fit in to the knob. It might be worth a shot to try scaling them down to around 95% and see how that goes.

You will need an M12-1.25 nut (I would recommend a nylock, which I did not use, so you can more easily adjust its alignment once it gets tight), 6 m3x20mm bolts and 6 m3 nuts.

author: Bdeitch

description.text:
This is a pneumatic extrusion based 3D printer designed specifically for printing clay and other paste materials, remixed from the exceptional work done by Jonathan Keep, Unfold, and models by Oliver Reinecke.

Specific remixes:
Scaled up to a 235mm diameter x 425mm height print volume. Uses 36 inch 12mm bearing rods and nominal 12 inch aluminum connecting rods (rod length is 335mm between pivot point centerlines).
Uses Uxcell (about 300cc) cartridges for the clay (lower initial cost compared to Techcon).
Includes a BOM with links to vendors (lots of eBay and Amazon) and includes total cost (updated as of May 2017).
Includes stl files for a modular printer center that can switch between Uxcell cartridges and a bowden extruder (modular_center.stl, Uxcell_Cartridge_insert.stl, Bowden_insert.stl), or the WASP Clay Extruder http://www.personalfab.it/en/products/clay-extruder-kit-2-0/ (appeared to be out of stock as of 14 January 2016, but is back in stock?). The bowden extruder is a WIP. Also a WIP is a DIY open version of a start/stop auger extruder (similar to what the WASP Clay Extruder does). I have attached my version New_Auger_Zibes_Quarter_Short.stl and a parts list, which is still a WIP. Many exciting versions in development can be found on Jonathan Keep's Google group (see link below).
Includes 3dm and dxf files for the CNC parts.
Includes the Marlin firmware (updated to 1.1.x) specific to this build (Zibes_Delta_2017,zip), as well as a starting config file for Slic3r (Zibes_Delta_2017). The configuration file also contains settings for the auger.

See the Google group on this topic (again thanks especially to Jonathan Keep for setting it up, and Dries Verbruggen at Unfold, and the rest of that community):
https://plus.google.com/communities/109375785524125994679?cfem=1

description.text: This is a tool for the OpenROV that slips onto the battery tube so that you can easily pull off the battery end tube caps without hurting your fingers. I've found that removing the rov's battery tube end caps with my fingers is challenging and painful because you have to forcefully use the tips of the fingers to slowly back off the cap. Also I do not think it would be possible to remove the caps if you were wearing gloves. Snap the puller onto the tube and place two fingers behind the tool and pull, the end cap will easily slide off because pressure is on the cap is evenly distributed. Video of it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ckg9T0Yartw

description.text: A mount to attach any item to the wrist of a Baxter Research Robot. This will be used to attach another camera or sensor to help with a pick-and-place sensor.

Print

Print at 0.3mm or finer

2 x collar.stl
1 x base.stl

Assembly

  1. Glue the collars to the base with a drop of acetone, so the opening is facing away from the rear of the base. You may need to trim the corners of the collars to fit.
  2. Use two or more cable ties in series to attach the base to Baxter's wrist.
  3. Cable tie additional components as needed, using the additional channels at the ends of the base.

title: Raspberry pi PC case and blade center

description.text: This is a stackable case for the raspberry pi that allows you to create a blade center type setup or you can mount one of these cases in a standard 5.25 PC mount and have a Pi in your PC. I've included an, untested, rack mount end plate that will allow you to mount this in 4U of space

EDIT:Uploaded an plate that should allow you to mount this into a standard 19 inch rack. I don't have a rack to test this on though, so let me know if it doesn't work out.

This case prints in two pieces, the receiver and the carrier. The carrier holds the pi, the receiver holds all of the cables. The idea is to have the receiver setup with all of your accessories, power and ethernet plugged into it. The carrier can be docked and undocked and holds itself in place using the pi's usb and ethernet ports. Power is supplied via a standard molex PC power supply and a 5.5mm barrel jack from a CCTV setup. You can print multiples of these and attach them top to bottom to create a blade center of sorts. Just use the PC mounting holes and a bit of plastic to join them together. Source 123d files available in my github https://github.com/scratchhax/3DPrinting/tree/master/Blade_Center

parts required:

USB extension cables, at least 6 inches. I use these.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MXCTDTC?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

5.5 mm barrel jacks from a CCTV setup. I use these.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XJ23W5Q?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01

Standard RJ45 Keystone jack

Molex 8981 male connector, I cut one off a $1 Molex to SATA power adapter.

author: Gorlath

description.text:
This is a very nice little puzzle. It’s easy to print (Top, Bottom, and Sticks Set) with no supports and requires little, if any, post-print finishing. It looks deceptively easy to solve, but it turns out to be a real challenge for many (most?) people. However, since it looks so straightforward, most people find it a joy to tinker with and will come back to it over and over until they finally solve it (or until you give them a hint).

The puzzle is somewhat smaller than it appears in the photos. It's actually about 118 mm. long x 60 mm. wide x 26 mm. tall.

Solution: The correct solution requires placing all 8 Sticks into the Box with each Stick lying flat on the bottom of the Box. No Stick can be tilted up, not even a tiny bit. Then the Box Top will easily fit back on the Box with all 8 Sticks comfortably inside. Trust me, there is plenty of room in the Box for all 8 Sticks when they are arranged correctly.

Please Note: Although I have not provided the solution here, I will respond to personal Thingiverse messages with questions about part sizes and/or printing accuracy. If you have trouble solving the puzzle once you have printed it, you can message me your email address, and I’ll send you the Solution Photo by return email. You may be surprised. . . Or, I can respond to your inquiry with a little ‘hint’ if you prefer. I will not use your email address for any other purpose, nor share it with anyone else. I promise.

Feel free to contact me with questions, comments, or suggestions. I would also like to have anyone who “Makes” this puzzle, thank me by taking a moment respond with “I Made One” with your puzzle’s photo and your comments.

Have Fun!

-mike-

PS: If you like this puzzle, you may want to take a look at my other, very similar, “Square Deal Puzzle”. Same concept, but with square Sticks instead of round ones. I’m not sure if one of them may be easier to solve than the other, but both print nicely and are very similar. -m-

I printed all the parts of the puzzle, in PLA Filament, on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation Printer using the following settings: Standard Presets; Infill=25%; Layer Height=0.20 mm; Shells=3; Raft=Yes; Supports=No. These settings produce a very nice puzzle in the least amount of time.

I printed the “Box” and “Top” using True Brown, and the “Sticks” using True Red. Print times were: Box=4h 8m; Top=1h 52m; Stick Set=3h 28m. I put the finished puzzle in a small zip-lock bag with all but the smallest piece inside the Box; I add the little Puzzle Teaser Label; and I include the smallest Stick inside the bag, but outside of the Box. See my Photos.

I have printed a dozen or more of these puzzles at this point – they make great gifts and they are fun to keep around as tabletop toys for friends and family visitors. None of them have required any post-print finishing. The Top fits a tiny bit snugly on the Box the first time you put them together, but they loosen up nicely very quickly. Just make sure to install and remove the Top by pushing it straight down and pulling it straight up (and not by tilting it, which may break off one of the small ‘pins’).

I included separate files for the individual Stick pieces in case they turn out to be needed, for whatever reason.

-mike-

comments.text: Several individuals have successfully 3D Printed this puzzle and have had some difficulty in solving it.  It is not a particularly easy puzzle to solve, but it can be solved with just a little patience and a bit of "out of the box" thinking.  :-)  Yes, that is a pun. . .    One question I am asked is: "What are the correct actual "as built" measurements of the Box?"  My original 3D CAD Design AS DESIGNED measurements are: Inside= 47.0mm x 92.0mm & Outside=63.0mm x 108.0mm.  I've carefully measured my finished puzzles, and the AS BUILT measurements are: Inside=46.6mm x 91.3mm & Outside=63.0mm x 107.7mm. My As Built measurements are consistent from one puzzle to the next over about a dozen individual puzzles which all work perfectly, leaving 1-2mm slack inside the Box with all the Sticks inside the Box and laying completely flat.

description.text:
Slide on fan shroud for hexagon hot end. Compatible with Cobblebot Basic and Beast printers. Fits a 40mm fan.

This is a remix/mashup up these two parts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945714 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:796756

They are modified versions of this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:972473

1. Print
  2. Remove hexagon hotend from mount
  3. Slide over the hexagon fan.
  4. Install fans
  5. Remount hexagon.
  6. Change necessary firmware settings and slicer settings if using V2 (fan kickstart in Marlin and fan control in slicer)

Version 1 (V1) is a single 40mm fan solution. Fan runs all the time, cooling the hotend and print bed at the same time. Some warping occurs because the initial layers of the print area are cooled.

Version 2 (V2) is a 3 fan solution. It uses a 40mm fan to cool the hexagon hotend, while two smaller (either 30mm or 25mm) fans cool the print area. The 40mm fan can run 100% of the time while the two smaller fans can cool the print area. This allows the small fans to be controlled by your gcode making sure you get the best prints.

This old hammer lost one of its striking surfaces.
This project prints a mold and stem base for a silicone rubber replacement. I used an RTV silicone rubber (Tinsil 70-60 Polytek) to pour the replacement hammer head. http://www.polytek.com/index.php?dispatch=categories.view&category_id=228 This is a high tensile strength, dense rubber.
The mold is about 25 ml in volume. Designed in trueSapce and printed on an Up!3D in ABS from Octave.

Print out the two parts.  
Mix up a small batch of High Tensile strength RTV (room temperature vulcanization) silicone rubber and pour the head.   
Don't worry about a release agent, nothing sticks to silicone.   
Place the base piece in to form the inner stem opening for the hammer.   
Place a small flat piece of wood down the side of the cured mold and walk the part out slowly.  
I used Goop as the glue but E600 would also work.

A Mjolnir replica modeled to work as a lamp. Its as close to movie prop size as I can make it and can be printed in sections. I tried to size the sections so that pretty much all printer beds could handle the pieces.

You will need support for the head items, use your own discretion as to how much etc.

I printed at a mix of .2 and .25 in a clear PLA from Esun. The gold embellishments were added using a mix of gold and copper paint pens.

You will need 1 of every part with the exception of the EndCaps x 2 and the HandleMidAndTop x 2

The locking tang slides over the top part of the handle and is screwed tight into the head.
The locking ring fits over the rounded hammer endcap on the top of the head

This is an atomic sturcture of rutile. The rutile-type structure is adopted by various dioxides, such as TiO2 (photocatalyst), GeO2, high-pressure SiO2, etc.

in each octahedron, a cation atom (e.g. Ti) is located at the center and six oxygen atoms are at the vertices.

By printing this model, you can understand the characteristics of rutile type-structure such as:

  • octahedra share horizontal edges,
  • octahedra of neighboring chains share its vertices,
  • there are space along c-axis (veritical line).

The stl file is made by Blender with a self-made python script.
This model was printed with a Cube 3 printer without automatic supporting materials.

description.text:
I picked up an adafruit Blinky Belt kit for my daughter. It required very little soldering and is nice and bright. The kit included a battery holder (with integrated switch) but nothing to enclose the circuitry or wiring. I wanted something a little more solid to hold and protect the board and batteries.
There is a follow-on version brewing in my head.

There is a writeup here: http://robotranch.org/blog/archives/160 Assemble the BlinkyBelt as suggested, up to the point of the battery box. Print the Bottom, End and Buckle. The end cap has some support material built-in which needs to be cut out. Cut some small holes near the edge and end of the blinky belt. Slide the end cap on and use zip-ties to attach. Print and assemble the battery pack. (Thing 5079) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079 (Parameterized battery pack with contacts by obijuan). Solder up the switch and power wires to the brain. Zip tie the wired end of the belt to base and plug the wire into the brain. Press the switches into place. Press the battery pack into the belt buckle. Align the holes of the buckle with the belt and switches. Before completely closing, slide the belt end into the box and close. Turn on switch and blink-out!

This thing incorporates elements from a number of designs but most resembles the feet that I chose as the base of the remix. About the name and the vibration resistance aspect...I HAVE NO IDEA IF THIS ACTUALLY WORKS! I should do some tests but have not gotten around to it. It could help, it could make no difference, it could even be a negative! Even without the springs I like the feet as it gives me some room under the printer for a little drawer!

There are two choices of leg style, one with straight corners and the other where they are beveled. I printed everything with a .2 layer height in PLA. Note that I use two springs in the front but three in the back as it is much heavier. The springs are a big variable and will depend on your material, your infill percentage, whether you have the filament spool on the back (I do not), etc. You will need to experiment. There are other things that could be used as well.

Introducing the (almost) completely 3D printable Universal Magazine Holster! Also known as a hard magazine pouch, this Thing provides a way to securely store your pistol magazine while also allowing for quick access.

Edit 9/20/15: I regret to inform you all that I had to remove this Thing from my loadout at the 10th annual combat rifle championship last weekend. While more action packed than most activities, this 3D printed mag pouch just isn't as strong as my injection molded one (thin wall ABS never seems to work well for me) and I observed a crack down the sides forming. I removed it because dropping a loaded mag is a penalty, though it is still usable for casual range days. I ended up winning some cool stuff though, I'll try and modify this to make it better when I get time.

Edit 8/29/15: It should be noted that single stack magazine retention has not been perfected. But, thanks to modular design, the retention strap is the only thing that will need to be reprinted.

I have seen other designs with retention, but they require a specific make/model of magazine and use the accuracy of the 3D printer (which can vary significantly especially across the entire Thingiverse!) to provide a snug fit on only one type of magazine.

This design uses a separate and custom retention strap to secure any magazine (double stack fits better) so it shouldn't fall out while crawling through a tunnel, pursuing a hostile, or doing any other intense physical activity (though I strongly recommend purchasing a commercial variant that is injection molded if your life depends on this).
I have included renders for viewing pleasure, followed by instructional pictures for installation, application..... and just some pictures of guns :D

See instructions tab for instructions.

On an end note I'd like to issue a public service announcement. Some readers may notice the prominently placed "No Excuse for Sexual Assault" cup surrounded by guns. This is in response to my recent (third) encounter with ANOTHER person who was molested as a young girl. She was also raped later on in life and we live in a society that seems to just brush this issue under the rug. ~3/4 of the women I have dated have been raped or have had a very close call and this is a startling statistic. She is very smart, and caring, and is also a Thingiverse user. Unfortunately she contemplates suicide because of her scars on top of being bullied at school because of her lovely nerdy nature (aren't all Thingiverse users? :P ).
As much as I'd love to think all rapists could be blown away by guns, unfortunately most rapes are committed by someone you know or under situations where it would be inappropriate to be carrying (i.e. at a party or bar with alcohol) in which case the best tool is vigilance. If you see something, say something. This underreported crime destroys lives, and leaves their victims desperate and suicidal, often with nightmares every night following. In my opinion this is worse than death, and unfortunately the victims often feel this way. For the less frequent occurrences of "stranger rape", like the poor soul jogging at 5AM at my university recently (edit: typo, a street nearby called 'north lawn' not the north lawn of the university), if you are the victim currently undergoing the assault you are well within your right to blast that bastard straight to hell (and please do, it does us all a favor). Unfortunately, it seems to me like it's the best shot at justice you'll have since we have courts and jury pools that believe this crime doesn't exist. I am still a strong advocate for self defense, and there's nothing that reliably levels the playing field in a fight like a gun.

Be sure to use quality hollow point ammunition such as the Winchester Ranger ammo pictured next to my Sig p938 in the demo of magazine fitting to avoid overpenatration and potential bystander injury.

Print as oriented in Makerware screenshot, though not all at the same time to facilitate more even layer cooling and better chances of success. coolarj10 has reported that the UniMag_Body1.1.stl can be printed vertically, though I am still testing this. My concern is the clip to hold the belt clip on will break over time putting that much stress on the layers, but maybe it doesn't bend enough.

The pictures are ordered to show beginning presenation/rendering, print orientation, assembly, modification (if necessary), and finally various magazines and their fit.

UniMag_Body1.1.stl should be printed with 100% infill, 1 shell, your choice of layer height (I used 0.2mm for all parts), and RAFT and SUPPORTS (unfortunately -- I did my best to avoid needing them).

UniMag_Clip1.1.stl
and
UniMag_Ret.stl
Should also be printed with 100% infill, 1 shell, and with raft and supports. See Makerware screenshot for recommended orientation.

I strongly recommend using ABS or some other thermoplastic with give due to the flexibility requirements of these parts.

Once all the parts are printed and support material removed -- I recommend a needle nose pliers -- use two #4x1/2" screws to attach the retention strap as shown in the renderings. For you lucky metric users, this comes out to a ~2.794x12.7mm wood screw. I prefer metric but there were imperial unit screws at the store. Thingiverse user coolarj10 reports that M3x10 screws will work, but I don't have access to these screws to test unfortunately. If your ABS part came out slightly warped like mine, some sanding in the areas indicated by the red arrows in the later pictures might be necessary.

The last step is to slide the belt clip into the body, shown in the renderings.

I have used my "replacement parts" clip:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963780
in a commercial hard magazine pouch in a few action matches and it hasn't broken yet. I haven't noticed any stress marks on the body or the retention strap, though, so I think they have been successfully tweaked to last a long time (the first version of the body did exhibit stress marks when installing/removing belt clip). Please let me know if you encounter any issues. Have fun, stay safe, and happy shooting! (and 3D printing!)

comments.text: Are .prt files the sources? If yes, how can I open them?
comments.author: fc93

comments.text: Yes they are, unfortunately they probably require proprietary software. I used NX, but Solidworks also supports them I think. I can upload STEP or IGES if you'd like, those are not source files per se, but they are not mesh files like STL so accurate dimensions can be derived using other software (but constraints and such will not transfer). I have yet to find an optimal solution to sharing 3D printed files, as these softwares that use these formats are still superior to open source options for designs with much complexity.
comments.author: fc93

comments.text: Hey, I made this and it's quite an interesting and good design. However, the retention clip doesn't to be holding my mags very well, could you make some other ones that are thicker (at least twice or three times as thick) to increase the amount of force on the mag? Also, what program did you use to make this and is it possible to have access to the source files so others may collaborate on it?
comments.author: AlbertP

comments.text: Yeah my buddy ran one of these in competition two matches ago and lost one while crawling through a tunnel. I also cracked one while crawling through the same tunnel due to forces on the structure even with acetone postprocessing. I think a V2 might be in the work at some point. Increasing the thickness of the retention clip might help, one user who posted a Make used some kind of adhesive rubber strip which seemed like a good idea. I'll upload the source files, I used NX.

Fitting the X belt to the K8200 is a nightmare,
So this mod not only makes things a little easier but also enables you to tension or loosen easily and quickly.

It uses two, 3/32" (2.5mm) screws; Minimum 1.5" (40mm) long.
With 7/32" (5.5mm) Hexagonal nuts.
And two, 5/32" (3.8mm) Bolts, with 9/32" (6.8mm) Hexagonal nuts.

First attempt to make a thing. After sanding a little bit, they fit nice and tight. Do not stress it too much or the pin will break off. Another weak point is the screw hole. If you screw it to tight, it can easily crack (as in my version with 4.5 mm from the outside).
